title: Angular speed of an unwrapping roll

content.question: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. The diagram shows a long, thin sheet of flexible metal that is wrapped many times around a plastic roller with radius <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Initially a small part of the metal sheet hangs vertically from the edge of the roller as shown in the above figures and the roller is held stationary. Point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></math> is marked on the side of the roller a distance <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the center of the roller. The mass of the metal sheet is far greater than the mass of the roller and frictional effects acting on the roller are assumed to be negligible. The roller is released at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and begins to rotate as the thin metal sheet unwinds from the roller. A student observes this situation for a time interval <math alttext="T" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></math> and records the angular velocity <math alttext="omega" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of time. The student determines that the mass of metal remaining on the axle changes by a negligible amount during time interval <math alttext="T" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></math>. To describe the motion of the roller over time, the student then fits the equation <math alttext="omega of t, equals A t cubed, plus B t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ω</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><msup><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to the data, where <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are positive constants. (a) As seen from the side view, what is the direction of the linear acceleration, if any, of point <math alttext="P" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></math>, at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

(e) Give a physical reason why the angular momentum of the roller increases with time.

After all the metal has unwound from the roller, the student measures the radius <math alttext="uppercase R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the roller to be <math alttext="20 centimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="20 radians per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mstyle><mrow><mtext>rad/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> respectively. Observed from the side, the roller rotates counterclockwise, as shown. A piece of clay of mass <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> strikes the very bottom edge of the roller with a horizontal velocity <math alttext="v equals 4.0 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> . The clay sticks to and rotates with the roller. The clay-roller system then rotates with a final angular velocity <math alttext="omega sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. (f) Is <math alttext="omega sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to <math alttext="omega sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Justify your answer.

The clay completes half of a single rotation and then loses contact with the roller when it is directly over the center of the roller. The clay travels forward and falls towards the ground and the roller continues to rotate at angular speed <math alttext="omega sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>ω</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> . (g) Describe how the rotational inertia of the roller-clay system relative to the center of the roller changes over time after the clay loses contact with the roller. Justify your answer. If the rotational inertia of the roller-clay system relative to the center of the roller does not change overtime, explicitly state this and justify your claim.
